title-group.article-title: Macroflora, paleogeography, and paleoecology of the Upper Cretaceous (Turonian?–Santonian) Saanich Member of the Comox Formation, Saanich Peninsula, British Columbia, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Carl H.W. Jonsson (e-mail: jonssonc@uvic.ca).

abstract.p: Morphotypes of plant macrofossil assemblages of the basal unit of the Upper Cretaceous (Turonian?–Santonian) Comox Formation, Nanaimo Group, Vancouver Island, were investigated to provide insight into the character of the macroflora, environment of deposition, and paleogeography of Vancouver Island. Three floristic assemblages were documented: one dominated by angiosperm morphotypes such as Platanus, Menispermites, and Zizyphus-like leaves; another dominated by gymnosperm morphotypes such as those synonymous with Glyptostrobus comoxensis Bell and Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward; and a third assemblage transitional between the previous two. These assemblages suggest the Saanich Member was likely deposited in a barrier island – estuarine floodplain complex with fluvial sedimentary input. The macrofloral assemblage also includes many endemic taxa, suggesting a barrier to floral migration between the paleocontinent and the Vancouver Island precursor during the Upper Cretaceous, which supports the existence of a third floristic province in North America during the Upper Cretaceous.

trans-abstract.p: Des morphotypes d’assemblages de macrofossiles végétaux de l’unité basale da la Formation de Comox du Groupe de Nanaimo (Crétacé supérieur, Turonien?–Santonien) sur l’île de Vancouver ont été étudiés dans le but de fournir un aperçu du caractère de la macroflore, de l’environnement de déposition et de la paléogéographie de l’île de Vancouver. Trois assemblages floristiques ont été documentés : le premier dominé par des morphotypes angiospermes tels que Platanus, Menispermites, et avec des feuilles de type Zizyphus; un autre dominé par des morphotypes gymnospermes, tels que ceux synonymes avec Glyptostrobus comoxensis Bell et Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward; ainsi qu’un troisième assemblage de transition entre les deux déjà mentionnés. Selon ces assemblages, le membre Saanich a probablement été déposé dans un complexe d’île barrière-estuaire-plaine inondable avec apport de sédiments fluviaux. L’assemblage macrofloral comprend aussi de nombreux taxons endémiques, suggérant une barrière à la migration florale entre le paléocontinent et le précurseur de l’île de Vancouver au Crétacé supérieur; cet assemblage supporte aussi l’existence d’une troisième province floristique en Amérique du Nord durant le Crétacé supérieur. [Traduit par la Rédaction]

sec.title: Introduction

caption.title: Map showing study area and locations of observed lithologies, attitudes of bedding planes. Locations of plant fossil localities and relative stratigraphic positions are represented broadly by their codes (see text for explanation). Other localities referred to in the text are indicated by single letter coding.

sec.p: The Nanaimo Group macroflora contains many unique taxa with most species described by Bell (1957) being new to science, thus suggesting that a distinct Upper Creataceous paleofloristic province existed on the west coast of North America. Pollen assemblage data support this concept, with the observation of a distinct “Continental Margin Province” here and in California, and unlike the coeval and well-studied Aquilapollenites and Normapolles provinces of the time ( Frederiksen 1987; Braman and Sweet 2012). However, plant fossil data from the Upper Cretaceous North American Cordillera is scarce, hindering on a comprehensive reconstruction of the paleofloral structure of North America.

In this study, we describe new fossil plant assemblages of the southern Comox Formation on Saanich Peninsula. We argue the case for floral endemism during the Upper Cretaceous of Vancouver Island and examine the evidence for placement of the Saanich Member within the Santonian. We also describe the environments of deposition as indicated by these plant assemblages.

sec.title: Geological and paleobotanical setting
sec.p: The age of the Comox Formation has been estimated to be within the mid- to late-Santonian, with the exception of Coniacian strata at the northern extent ( Mustard 1994), based on an age corroborated by radiometric (U–Pb) dating of an Upper Comox Formation (Dunsmuir Member) tuff near Quinsam on Vancouver Island ( Kenyon et al. 1992). However, being almost entirely terrestrial, the lower limit of the Comox Formation is poorly constrained because of the lack of age-diagnostic marine fossils ( Mustard 1994). The recent discoveries of Turonian strata in the southern part of the basin have called the age of the Comox Formation on Saanich Peninsula into question ( Haggart 1991, 1994; Haggart et al. 2005).

The overlying Late Santonian Haslam Formation ( Mustard 1994) provides a well-established age constraint for the upper limit of the Saanich Member because the Haslam Formation forms conformable contacts with the Saanich Member in places ( Mustard 1994; Johnstone 2006). Turonian-aged mollusc fossils in the Barnes and Sidney Island formations, which likely constrain the basal age of the Saanich Member, occur to the immediate southeast of the study area and appear to extend the southern Nanaimo Group sedimentary record back in time ( Haggart 1991, 1994; Haggart et al. 2005). Haggart et al. (2005) suggested that a conformable record may exist between the base of the Comox Formation and the Barnes and Sidney Island formations within the southern extent of the Nanaimo Group. Alternatively, both the Barnes and Sidney Island formations may be marine equivalents of the adjacent terrestrial deposits of the Comox Formation ( Haggart et al. 2005).
To date no conformable contact has been observed between the Barnes or Sidney Island formations and the Comox Formation.

By the Upper Cretaceous, angiosperms dominated on land and occupied almost every habitat ( Coiffard et al. 2012) and latitude ( Crane and Lidgard 1989). Recent detailed work on European macrofloras ( Coiffard and Gomez 2010; Coiffard et al. 2006, 2007, 2012) provides an excellent model for Cretaceous macrofloras, which compares well with data from North America ( Coiffard et al. 2012). According to these workers, angiosperms came to dominate most freshwater-adjacent environments by the Cenomanian in Europe beginning with Barremian–Aptian freshwater lakeshores and wetlands, followed by Albian fluvial systems, and lastly marine-associated wetlands ( Coiffard et al. 2012). However, gymnosperms still remained dominant adjacent to marine settings due to their relatively high tolerance to brackish and marine shoreline conditions relative to contemporary angiosperms that had not yet developed adaptations for marine coastal environments ( Coiffard et al. 2012). Certain groups of angiosperms flourished in particular environments at the time. Platanoid trees, for instance, were abundant adjacent to disturbed freshwater settings, and in fluvial systems in particular ( Boyd 1993; Coiffard et al. 2006). This ecological pattern in the Upper Cretaceous provides a useful tool for interpreting depositional settings and does not rely on fine taxonomic resolution.

sec.title: Methods and materials
sec.p: The study material consisted of 942 individual fossils from 459 slabs collected at various times from within the study area and deposited in the Earth History collection at the Royal British Columbia Museum (RBCM) in Victoria, British Columbia. As requested by local paleontological organizations, the coordinates of sample localities are not published here, but they are available at the RBCM for research purposes. Site locations are indicated next to general areas of occurrence on the regional map ( Fig. 1) in their geological context. All slabs examined for this study are from sites on the Saanich Peninsula and Goudge Island, which are locations previously interpreted to represent the Saanich Member ( Johnstone 2006). Field observations of sediment type and stratigraphy were also made throughout the study area over two occasions to establish a geological context ( Fig. 1) and to facilitate comparison of fossil sites.

sec.title: Morphotype analysis
sec.p: Fossils in this study were grouped into morphotype categories defined by similarity with a single designated specimen (morphotype specimen) or specimens (paramorphotype specimens) within the collection. Character traits used to distinguish these categories for angiosperm leaves were based on the Manual of Leaf Architecture ( Ellis et al. 2009). Nonangiosperm morphotypes were grouped according to features, which distinguish categories yet accommodate variability within obviously similar groups. For instance, vegetative branches of Glyptostrobus comoxensis Bell were classified into one of five morphotypes based on leaf morphology and crowding as well as branch thickness. This strategy allows database information to be applied directly to future scientific questions since these morphotype categories preserve morphologic data. Morphotypes were also associated with previously described species with the result that several morphotypes could represent a single species. This association with binomial names was necessary for comparison with other Upper Cretaceous floras in literature and aided in the estimates of species diversity presented here. For the purpose of counting, individual fossils were considered as either the detached leaf(let) (most angiosperm leaves) or the whole of a stem with attached leaves (mostly Pinales branches).

All data were analyzed in LibreOffice Calc (ver. 4.3.5.2.0) and imported into RStudio (ver. 0.98.1091)/R (ver. 3.1.2) for graphical analysis. Data were grouped by site and into broad taxanomic categories after Coiffard and Gomez (2010) and Coiffard et al. (2006, 2007, 2012) as appropriate for comparisons. Assemblages of 25 or fewer specimens are included in tables, but because of the small sample size they are not discussed in further detail.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of the 942 fossils examined, 915 were assigned to Plantae of which 785 specimens could be placed into one of 60 morphotypes ( Appendix Table A1). The remainder were placed into taxonomic categories if possible, which resulted in 872 specimens confidently placed within a broad taxonomic group; 599 of these fossils were confidently assigned to previously described species ( Table A1). The latter were represented by 33 morphotypes assigned to 17 species ( Table A1). Fragmentation, post-depositional alteration, and poor preservation of material from this area prevented resolving the remaining morphotypes confidently to species. Of the morphotypes not assigned to species, 28 were successfully placed in the broader taxonomic groupings necessary for analysis. The remaining three morphotypes could not be placed ( Table A1).

Eudicotyledonous angiosperm leaf morphotypes (31 morphotypes) dominated the assemblages overall. Pinales had relatively large morphotypic diversity as well (13 morphotypes). However, much of the morphotypic diversity in Pinales is accounted for by intraspecies variation with G. comoxensis and Araucaurites longifolia Newberry being represented by five and two morphotypes, respectively ( Table A1). This pattern is reflected in species estimates here ( Table 1). Other groups such as ferns contributed a total of five or fewer morphotypes to the assemblage ( Table 1). This resulted in roughly half the morphotypic richness being accounted for by eudicots ( Table 1). Gymnosperm (Cycadales and Pinales) fossil abundance is comparable to that of angiosperms, with Pinales fossils numerically about as abundant as eudicots ( Table 1).

caption.title: Morphotype and estimated species diversity for broad plant groups of the Saanich Member.

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: Only groups represented in the dataset are shown. Since estimates of species diversity are based on subjective factors, data reported are ranges estimated by counting suspected species. Where indicated with a superscripted number one, suspected species are based on nonmorphotyped specimens where the material was too poor to make a proper judgement.

fn.p: Normalized abundances are calculated by calculating the percent abundance at each site where the sample size is greater than 25 (to avoid errors associated with small sample sizes) and averaging the resulting values for each group shown.

sec.p: The relative proportion of fossil groups varies among sites with morphotypes assigned to the Taxodioid Cupressaceae group being the most abundant overall ( Fig. 2). However, at sites BR4 and BR2 numerous eudicot morphotypes including those assigned to the Platanaceae group predominate ( Fig. 2). Cycads occur in large numbers at most well-sampled sites, with the exception of NR1, BR2, and AP, in which their abundance coincided with the infrequent occurrence of angiosperms ( Fig. 2). Platanaceae group leaves are also somewhat abundant at site NR1, and morphotypes grouped with Menispermaceae had a high abundance at one site (BR4; Fig. 2).

caption.title: Abundance of fossil plants grouped by selected taxonomic groups and site. Only data from sites marked with an asterisk (*) consisted of more than 25 specimens and are considered significant.

sec.p: When morphotypes are associated with species, the overall morphotypic diversity is highest at the best sampled sites BR4, BR2, and BR3 ( Fig. 3). Sites BR1 and AP are exceptions to this pattern having only seven and five plant species, respectively, despite large sample sizes. Taxodioid Cupressaceae, in spite of abundance, were only represented by one species, G. comoxensis, and occurred at all sites ( Fig. 3).

caption.title: Fossil plant morphotype counts by selected taxonomic groups and site. Note the change in scale for each graph. Only data from sites marked with an asterisk (*) consisted of more than 25 specimens and are considered significant.

sec.p: When species data are compared to occurrence data from literature on the Nanaimo Group, the flora was most like that of the Comox Formation with 13 species in common compared to 10 in common with the next most similar assemblage from the Extension Formation ( Table 2). Comparison with global occurrence data from literature on Cretaceous floras indicates there are five of 17 well-represented species in this assemblage that are only documented from the Nanaimo Group and three more with occurrences only from the Cretaceous of Vancouver Island and the North American Cordillera ( Table 3). This analysis also yielded biostratigraphic ranges for 18 of the species listed, which indicates most of these species occur in Campanian strata ( Fig. 4).

caption.title: Saanich flora in the Nanaimo Group.

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: Species listed are limited to those with adequate material for comparison with data elsewhere. Only terrestrial formations of the Nanaimo Group are shown, as other units have no published occurrences. Except where indicated, these data are drawn from prior works ( Appendix B). Direct comparison of morphotype category occurrences was not possible, as macrofossils in prior literature are listed by binomial names.

fn.p: Bell (1957) considered this species closely allied to Artocarpus lessiginia (Lesquereux) Knowlton; however, the available material to date is too fragmentary for close comparison.
Personal observation based on collection at the Royal BC Museum.
Previous work documented this occurrence as tentative, and this study confirms presence in the Comox Formation.

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: Species listed are limited to those with adequate material for comparison with data elsewhere. None of these species have been observed in the reviewed literature outside the regions listed here. Unless otherwise indicated all occurrences shown in this table are drawn from works listed in Appendix B.

fn.p: British Columbian Cordillera. Data for plant fossils for the Upper Cretaceous in the North American Cordillera, excluding Alaska, is limited to British Columbia at present (see discussion).
Not previously documented from the Comox Formation prior to this study.
Bell (1957) considered this species closely allied to A. lessiginia (Lesquereux) Knowlton; however, the available material to date is too fragmentary for close comparison.

caption.title: Biostratigraphic chart showing the temporal distributions of species identified elsewhere within the Upper Cretaceous. These data were restricted to occurrences where the age of the host rock is well known.

sec.p: Geologically, three general types of rocks were observed at outcrops in the study area. Observed were a basal facies consisting of coarse pebbly litharenites at Armstrong Point ( Fig. 1, site A); coarse litharenites at Tatlow Road ( Fig. 1, site B); and fine litharenites observed at Hoth Hill, Laurel Road, and the southern point at the north Tsehum Harbor site ( Fig. 1, sites C, D, and E). This facies is found in unconformable contact with Wrangellian basement rock at Armstrong Point (see arrow on Fig. 1, site A). One plant fossil locality (AP) is located within the coarser sandstones near this contact.

A second facies consists of grey and tan finely laminated and massive mudstones with some litharenite beds. This facies outcrops along most of Hickory Drive ( Fig. 1, site F), Nymph Point ( Fig. 1, site G), on the beach near Madrona Road ( Fig. 1, site H), and the northern part of the north Tsehum Harbor site ( Fig. 1, site E). Localized sandstone lenses occur at the Tsehum Harbor site but lack any textures that may indicate channel fill deposition. All plant fossil localities, except AP, are located within this facies. When plant assemblage type was compared to the matrix type in which it was contained, no relationship was found ( Table 4). A poorly preserved bivalve fossil was found within mudstone talus found at the Tsehum Harbor site, and sandstone beds at the same site contain Teredolites ichnofossils.

caption.title: Summary of floral assemblages observed in the Saanich Member on Saanich Peninsula, British Columbia.

oasis:row.oasis:entry: Glyptostrobus comoxensis Bell, Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward
Zizyphus cretaceous (Dawson) Bell, Ziziphoides neilii (Dawson) Bell, Menispermites spp., Platanus affinis (Lesquereux) Bell
Mixed assemblage of A1 and A2

sec.p: A third facies in the study area outcrops at the north end of Hickory Drive and Highview Place ( Fig. 1, site I) and consists of medium-grained sandstones with hummocky crossbeds, and weathered bivalve fossils were found. These rocks are found in sharp contact with the underlying siltstone facies at one locality (Highview Place). No plant fossils were recovered from this facies.

sec.title: Floral endemism
sec.p: Notably, several morphotypes from the study area have yet to be found outside the Nanaimo Group ( Table 2). Two possible explanations for this floristic distinctness are possible: the Nanaimo Group flora was part of a latitudinally extensive and unique Upper Cretaceous west coast North American floral province, or the flora was physically isolated on Wrangellia and separated from western North America. Neither of these possibilities can be ruled out at this point, primarily because the Upper Cretaceous floras of western North American (excluding those of Alaska and Vancouver Island) are poorly understood.

On the nearby continental mainland, Zizyphus cretaceus (Dawson) Bell and Nilssonia vancouverensis (Dawson) Bell also occur at Lang Creek on the continental mainland. This occurrence was used by Bradley (1973) to correlate Lang Creek rocks with the Comox Formation. Glyptostrobus comoxensis and Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell were identified at Reynold’s Creek of east-central British Columbia ( Rouse 1967). The connections between these two mainland localities and early Nanaimo Group floras are, however, weak. The Lang Creek assemblage was a preliminary assemblage that was not formally published after a brief description in 1967. The assemblage was based on only 72 specimens, most of which were only identified to the level of genus ( Bradley 1973). Both of the species in common with the Comox Formation could easily be misidentified if preserved poorly or as fragments.

The Reynold’s Creek occurrences are doubtful for other reasons. Glyptostrobus comoxensis at Reynold’s Creek is based on vegetative branches and detached cones ( Rouse 1967). Both these elements can be confused with those of some specimens of Glyptostrobus nordenskioldii Brown (= Cryptomerites lambii Bell) known from the Paleocene of Alberta (compare Rouse 1967, pls. 1–2, figs. 6–11 with Bell 1949, pl. 30, figs. 1, 5; Rouse 1967 pl. 6, fig. 23 with Bell 1949, pl. 32, fig. 4). Notably, the cones from Saanich Peninsula sites were found attached (see Fig. A1 a ) and differ from those originally associated with G. comoxensis. In summary, both mainland British Columbia examples lack sufficient detail to conclude that they represent the same paleofloral province as the Comox Formation.

Microfossil data support the assertion of the endemic character of the Saanich Member macroflora. Pollen assemblages from the west coast of North America suggest that a unique floristic province was associated with allochthonous terranes. Frederiksen (1987) called the distinct microfloristic assemblage the Continental Margin Floristic Province. The assemblage contains several endemic pollen palynomorphs and includes Nanaimo Group pollen assemblages on Vancouver Island, and immediately adjacent Upper Cretaceous cores from the Vancouver metropolitan area ( Rouse et al. 1971). Fredriksen (1987) also included sites from the La Panza Range and San Rafael Mountains of California in this province. These pollen assemblages differ from the Aquilapollenites assemblages found east of the Cordillera ( Rouse et al. 1971; Fredriksen 1987) and at least one Upper Cretaceous formation in the San Joaquin Valley of California ( Fredriksen 1987). The La Panza Range and San Rafael Mountains of California were once part of exotic terranes that accreted at roughly the same time as Wrangellia. Despite this evidence for a unique floristic province, additional micro- and macrofossil localities need to be studied along the western cordillera to verify its occurrence.

sec.title: Depositional setting and age
sec.p: Earlier sedimentological studies interpreted the Saanich Member to represent a storm-swept shoreline having a protected embayment/barrier island complex ( Johnstone et al. 2006; Johnstone 2006). Our lithological observations are consistent with this interpretation and further extend the geographic occurrence of this facies and presumed depositional environment westward towards the opposite side of Saanich Peninsula to include those occurring at Madrona Drive ( Fig. 1, site H).

Marine-associated ichnofossils such as Teredolites found within the study area and the occurrence of poorly preserved bivalves at BR2 and within associated talus clearly indicate the occurrence of marine conditions near the sites of deposition of plant material. The hummocky crossbeds at site I ( Fig. 1) further suggest that parts of the Saanich Member were likely deposited on sandy beaches along a stormy coast, possibly exposed to the open ocean.

Notably, all our sites, except those on Tatlow Road and at Armstrong point ( Fig. 1, sites B and A, respectively), consist of medium- to fine-grained sandstones or mudstones and for the most part lack pebbles and conglomerates associated with other facies of the Saanich Member ( Johnstone 2006; Johnstone et al. 2006). Most of these rocks are also finely laminated, which suggests a quiet water environment associated with the active shoreline proposed by Johnstone et al. (2006).

The character of the macrofloral assemblages and physical conditions of these fossils imply that the Saanich Member was deposited in quiet, possibly estuarine, waters. As noted earlier, we identified three types of assemblage ( Table 4): one dominated by gymnosperms (A1; sites AP and BR1), another dominated by angiosperms (A2; sites BR2, BR3 and BR4), and one a mixed assemblage type of both A1 and A2 morphotypes (A3; sites NR1, GI). Assemblage A1 is characterized by the ubiquitous presence of gymnosperms, particularly the morphotypes diagnosed as G. comoxensis ( Fig. A1 a ) and Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward ( Fig. A1 b ). A2 is defined by the abundant presence of morphotypes assigned to Z. cretaceus ( Fig. A1 c ), other Zizyphus-like morphotypes as well as numerous sapindaceous, Menispermaceae ( Fig. A1 d ), and Platanaceae morphotypes ( Fig. A1 e ). The third assemblage is similar to both A1 and A2 in composition, but it contains only a moderate abundance of eudicot morphotypes, and a moderate abundance of gymnosperm morphotypes.

These three macrofloral assemblages are readily attributable to either floodplains or wetland settings influenced by brackish water ( Table 4). Assemblage A1 (sites AP, BR1) contains a low diversity of morphotypes but also abundant gymnosperm remains (see Figs. 2, 3). Angiosperm leaves from these sites are often torn and damaged, suggesting they were transported some distance. Leaves of cycads in contrast are mostly intact, suggesting they may have originated from plants growing nearby and were not transported far prior to deposition. Like modern cycads, Cretaceous cycad leaves were probably more robust than contemporaneous angiosperm leaves and may have undergone transport some distance with limited wear. We infer only short distance transport of cycad leaves because there is little or no sign of wear. Mats of overlapping branches of G. comoxensis were likely deposited close to their source (at BR1 for instance). Accordingly, we interpret A1 to have been formed from local gymnosperm-dominated habitats downstream of angiospermous sites.

In contrast, assemblage A2 (sites BR2, BR3, and BR4) contains abundant and diverse angiosperm leaves. At these localities, leaves of the same morphotype are commonly found deposited in close association with other leaves of the same or similar morphotype. These leaves are often distributed in mats one upon the other and are intact, suggesting they were deposited from plants of the immediate area rather than transported a long distance. The third macrofloral assemblage A3, contains abundant gymnosperms and a diversity of angiosperm fossils (sites NR1, GI on Figs. 2, 3). Angiosperm leaves found at these sites show signs of transport such as laminar tears; however, the leaves only occasionally overlap.

Other studies of Upper Cretaceous macrofloral ecology have associated angiosperm assemblages of this age with floodplain regimes, while associating gymnosperm assemblages in marginal marine settings (see review in Coiffard et al. 2012). Cycads may be an especially good indicator of brackish water settings since brackish water wetlands were not favored environments of Cretaceous angiosperms relative to contemporary gymnosperms ( Coiffard et al. 2012). The abundant G. comoxensis morphotypes found in these assemblages may be a result of the same ecological differentiation. The paleoecological context in which these morphotypes occur is difficult to assess; however, moderate tolerance to saltwater flooding in living barrier island Cupressaceae species ( Juniperus virginiana) has been experimentally documented ( Tolliver et al. 1997).

Taken together, the Saanich Member macrofloral assemblages may have developed from leaves and even stems transported by rivers or streams into a coastal depositional basin such as an estuary or lagoon. In re-considering the age of the strata, our observations support the assignment of the Saanich Member to the Comox Formation ( Mustard 1994). Johnstone et al. (2006) regarded the Saanich Member as equivalent to the Sidney Island Formation on the basis of lithological similarity, and hence regarded the combined units to extend continuously from Santonian back into the Turonian. However, no continuous section linking these stratigraphic units has been described. Biostratigraphic comparisons of macrofossil assemblages with global occurrence data suggest a younger Campanian age for the Saanich Member ( Fig. 4). With the age of the immediately overlying Haslam Formation being well established as Late Santonian, the Saanich Member deposits on Saanich Peninsula are likely not much older than this. Considering the few global occurrences of the species found in the Saanich Member flora, a plant-based biostratigraphic age may not be especially reliable. Accordingly, in absence of convincing data otherwise, the Saanich Member should be regarded as Santonian.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The Saanich member macroflora consists of a diverse assemblage of angiosperms and gymnosperms with much of the diversity within the angiosperms. The fossil macroflora most closely resembles previously described Comox Formation assemblages. Many plant fossil taxa are unique to the Nanaimo Group such as Z. cretaceus, G. comoxensis, and Menispermites torosus Bell adding to the evidence for a unique floristic province on the west coast of North America. These observations provide a framework to discuss the geographic isolation of Wrangellia during the Upper Cretaceous and may help develop our understanding of both the floral context and the paleogeographic interpretation of Wrangellia and other allochthonous terranes of western North America. However, more sites of a similar age in western North America need to be discovered and studied. The Saanich Member macroflora and associated sediments suggest deposition in a fluvial to marginal marine setting including floodplain, estuarine, and lagoonal environments. Future investigations are needed to examine the floras of the Upper Cretaceous west coast of North America and to stratigraphically connect the Saanich Member with nearby Turonian strata on Barnes and Sidney islands.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This work was supported by a number of staff and volunteers at the Royal British Columbia Museum including Marji Johns and Charlotte Swanson who contributed time and logistical support. Thor Henrich and Raymond Graham provided insightful discussions about the paleofloristic and geological problems herein. We also thank two anonymous reviewers for their input.

sec.title: Appendix A. Plant fossil occurrences for sites within the Saanich Peninsula study area

caption.title: Morphotype occurrence data for Saanich Member sites by inferred taxonomic grouping and species or genus used for the analyses in this study.

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: Morphotypes in bold correspond to those figured in Figs. A1 through A5 in this appendix.

caption.title: The table shows previously documented occurrences of Saanich Peninsula Upper Cretaceous plant fossils and the age of that locality.

oasis:row.oasis:entry: Protophyllocladus polymorpha (Lesquereux) Berry, Menispermites reniformis Dawson
Platanus affinis (Lesquereux) Bell (= P. primaeva), Liriodendron giganteum (pl. 25, fig 1; pl. 26 fig 5 only; = L. meekii pl. 28, fig. 6)

Protophyllocladus polymorpha (Lesquereux) Berry, Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward, Menispermites reniformis Dawson, Magnolia rhamnoides, Liriodendron giganteum, Platanus affinis (Lesquereux) Bell, Ziziphoides neilii (Dawson) Bell
Atane Formation–vicinity of Atanikerluk (Kingittoq member inferred)

Artocarpus occidentalis (Dawson) Bell, Cladophlebis vahliana Heer, Cladophlebis sp. B. Bell, Menispermites torosus Bell, Nilssonia vancouverensis (Dawson) Bell, Protophyllocladus polymorpha (Lesquereux) Berry, Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward, Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell, Sapindus pacificus, Zizyphus cretaceus, Ziziphoides neilii (Dawson) Bell
Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward, Nilssonia vancouverensis (Dawson) Bell, Menispermites torosus Bell

Cladophlebis sp. B. Bell Protophyllocladus polymorpha (Lesquereux) Berry, Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward, Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell
Glyptostrobus comoxensis Bell, Protophyllocladus polymorpha (Lesquereux) Berry, Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell, Sapindus pacificus, Ternstroemites harwoodensis
Vancouver Colliery (Extention Fm according to Bell, 1957)
Nilssonia vancouverensis (Dawson) Bell (= Macrotaeniopteris vancouverensis), Artocarpus occidentalis (Dawson) Bell (= Artocarpophyllum occidentale), Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell (= Cornus obesus)
Wellington Colliery (Extention Fm according to Bell, 1957)

Protophyllocladus polymorpha (Lesquereux) Berry (= Adiantites praelongus), Platanus affinis (Lesquereux) Bell (= P. primaeva), Ternstroemites harwoodensis (= Ficus laurophyllidia), Liriodendron giganteum (= L. praetulipiferum), Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell (= Magnolia occidentalis)

caption.title: Key fossil plants from the flora of the Saanich Member. Shown here are vegetative branches (RBCM.BR.001) and cones (RBCM.BR.038, see arrow) of ( a) Glyptostrobus comoxensis Bell, ( b) Pseudoctenis latipennis (Heer) Seward (RBCM.BR.002), ( c) Zizyphus cretaceus (Dawson) Bell (RBCM.BR.027), ( d) Menispermites reniformis Dawson (RBCM.BR.013), and ( e) Platanus affinis (Lesquereux) Bell (RBCM.BR.010). All associated scale bars are 1 cm long. The original photographs for this figure were cropped, adjusted for brightness and contrast, and then transformed to grayscale to enhance the visibility of fossil features with grayscale printing.

Fossil plants of the Saanich Member: Ferns and Gymnosperms ( a) Sphenopteris hollicki (Knowlton) Bell (RBCM.GI.005), ( b) Cladophlebis ( Gleichenites ?) vahliana Heer (RBCM.BR.022), ( c) morphotype RBCM.BR.007, ( d) morphotype RBCM.BR.005, ( e) Araucaurites longifolia Newberry (RBCM.BR.003), ( f) Amentotaxus cf. campbelli (Gardner) Florin (RBCM.NR.002), and ( g) RBCM.BR.008. Scale bars are 1 cm. The original photographs for this figure were cropped, adjusted for brightness and contrast, and then transformed to grayscale to enhance the visibility of fossil features with grayscale printing.

Angiosperm morphotypes of the Saanich Member: ( a) RBCM.BR.015, ( b) Menispermites torosus Bell (RBCM.BR.018), ( c) M. cf. septentrionalis Hollick (RBCM.BR.012), ( d) Liriodendron giganteum Lesquereux (RBCM.BR.031), ( e) RBCM.BR.035, and ( f) RBCM.NR.003. Scale bars are 1 cm. The original photographs for this figure were cropped, adjusted for brightness and contrast, and then transformed to grayscale to enhance the visibility of fossil features with grayscale printing.

Fossil plants of the Saanich Member: ( a) Sapindus pacificus (Dawson) Bell (RBCM.BR.032), ( b) RBCM.BR.033, ( c) RBCM.BR.036, ( d) RBCM.GI.003, ( e) Artocarpus occidentalis (Dawson) Bell (RBCM.BR.017), and ( f) RBCM.BR.021. Scale bars are 1 cm. The original photographs for this figure were cropped, adjusted for brightness and contrast, and then transformed to grayscale to enhance the visibility of fossil features with grayscale printing.

Fossil plants of the Saanich Member. Morphotypes ( a) RBCM.NP.001, ( b) RBCM.NP.002, ( c) RBCM.HV.001, ( d) Rhamnites eminens (Dawson) Bell (RBCM.NR.009), and ( e) Ziziphoides neillii (Dawson) Bell (RBCM.BR.025). Scale bars are 1 cm. The original photographs for this figure were cropped, adjusted for brightness and contrast, and then transformed to grayscale to enhance the visibility of fossil features with grayscale printing.
